articles.headline: Parents and Students Plead With Trump: ‘How Many Children Have to Get Shot?’
articles.snippet: An afternoon listening session in the State Dining Room included those affected by school shootings in Parkland, Fla.; Littleton, Colo.; and Newtown, Conn.
articles.abstract: An afternoon listening session in the State Dining Room included those affected by school shootings in Parkland, Fla.; Littleton, Colo.; and Newtown, Conn.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An anguished father mourning his 18-year-old daughter vented his anger and pleaded for safer schools.

articles.headline: Ford Ousts Chief of North American Unit for ‘Inappropriate Behavior’
articles.snippet: The carmaker declined to elaborate on what led to the departure of Raj Nair, who had been with the company for three decades and had led its North American operations since June.
articles.abstract: The carmaker declined to elaborate on what led to the departure of Raj Nair, who had been with the company for three decades and had led its North American operations since June.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ford Motor ousted one of its most senior officials on Wednesday over what it called “inappropriate behavior,” adding to the turmoil at a company already struggling to lift its profits and plot a new strategic course.

articles.headline: Hotel Carrying New Trump Brand Secures $6 Million Tax Break
articles.snippet: The first of the Trumps’ Scion hotels is being built in the Mississippi Delta. The local developers, saying it would draw tourists, sought state tax relief.
articles.abstract: The first of the Trumps’ Scion hotels is being built in the Mississippi Delta. The local developers, saying it would draw tourists, sought state tax relief.
articles.lead_paragraph: The State of Mississippi on Wednesday awarded a tax break worth up to $6 million for a hotel project involving the Trump family business, a public subsidy that could indirectly benefit President Trump.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Ben Protess

articles.headline: An Envoy Who Can Rival ‘North Korea’s Ivanka’
articles.snippet: Administration officials say that Ivanka Trump could smooth some of the tensions that flared during the vice president’s visit, even if they insist that is not the purpose of her trip.
articles.abstract: Administration officials say that Ivanka Trump could smooth some of the tensions that flared during the vice president’s visit, even if they insist that is not the purpose of her trip.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the sister of Kim Jong-un made her historic visit to the Winter Olympics in South Korea two weeks ago, saying nothing but commanding noisy press coverage, the South Korean news media quickly called her “North Korea’s Ivanka.”

articles.headline: Complaints About Nursing Home Evictions Rise, and Regulators Take Note
articles.snippet: One reason for the evictions, legal advocates say, is that the residents’ better-paying Medicare coverage is ending and will be replaced by Medicaid.
articles.abstract: One reason for the evictions, legal advocates say, is that the residents’ better-paying Medicare coverage is ending and will be replaced by Medicaid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six weeks after Deborah Zwaschka-Blansfield had the lower half of her left leg amputated, she received some news from the nursing home where she was recovering: Her insurance would no longer pay, and it was time to move on.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Trump Suggests Teachers Get a ‘Bit of a Bonus’ to Carry Guns
articles.snippet: President Trump promoted arming specially trained teachers to fend off school shooters, but rejected active-shooter drills to survive a rampage.
articles.abstract: President Trump promoted arming specially trained teachers to fend off school shooters, but rejected active-shooter drills to survive a rampage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Thursday enthusiastically embraced a National Rifle Association position to arm highly trained teachers to fortify schools against mass shootings like the one last week. Mr. Trump, who said the armed teachers should receive extra pay as an incentive, promoted his idea as demands for stronger gun control intensified across the country.
